title: Personally I think Riot dun goofed on these 1HKO spells.
body:
{{champion:25}} {{champion:412}} {{champion:53}} Qs should not exist in this game.

An example of a /good/ high CC skillshot, IMO is:

Shoots goo in a line, deals damage and the target is snared for 1/1.5/2/2.5/3 seconds. When the target receives total damage equal 25% of it's max HP, the goo explodes dealing bonus damage and breaking the CC effect.

I get high priority skillshots should exist in some form, but come on man; these hooks are not fair at all.

Yep. Pretty much every mobility 'counter' hurts immobile champions more.

The problem is that unless you implement a point-and-click mechanic that ONLY stops mobility spells, then based on the way the game is balanced, it is nigh-impossible to punish the mobile more than the immobile. Point-and-click stuns (A la Taric, Lissandra) punish the immobile more than the mobile because it's easier for them to reach the immobile champion. Snares punish both equally, however since the immobile champion is always easier to get to, it'll end up affecting him more often, thereby hurting him more than a mobile champion. Silence prevents mobility skills that the immobile don't have, but that spell is being phased out because of community talking since it also eliminates any sort of ability-based response to a threat until it's done. 

The reason those abilities, and abilities like them, are considered to be even part of a counter to them is because most mobile champions are squishy as all hell, so if they no longer have direct control over their movement, then they will die. Meanwhile, if you look at comparatively immobile champions like Mundo, Volibear, Olaf, Galio, Morde, Nasus, Singed, Garen, etc., then you see they all want to be in the middle of the fight because without mobility, they can have plenty of durability packed directly into their kit, or be encouraged to build much tankier. They're the bruisers in the pit, while the mobile are dancers trying to avoid the pit or they'll die.

Unfortunately, there isn't much of a way to balance mobile vs. immobile at this point.

If whoever reading this hasn't caught on by now, I'm referring to a Rupture mechanic (Not {{champion:31}}) that Riot has previously called a poor design mechanic.
to be fair not all mobility skills are problematic. The ones that are are those with very little cd.

So then, must we consider that any champion built around mobility and little else is problematic? 

Mobility itself is rarely the issue; the issue is when it's paired with something devastating. Every time I look at complaints about mobility I kind of realize that the only time mobility is really brought up is when it's paired with one specific trait: damage. Mobility is brought up as a trait of survivability, though without any upfront tankiness, so when the champion in question also does high damage (old Kassadin, Fizz, LeBlanc, Early-game Lee Sin, Katarina, Kha'zix, Nidalee, etc) that's when it becomes a problem. 

It seems the League community doesn't want anything resembling the trope of "Fragile Speedster" in the game, despite the fact that the game is practically made for them, so why wouldn't they be here?

Mobility is very powerful both offensively and defensively. This makes champions who can both resist ganks and push forward an advantage, meaning that mobile champions who snowball become very hard to stop, and it also makes it very difficult to shut them down through team support. Low counterplay kits are the main source of oppressive snowballing, and mobility makes that worse.

As for out of lane, mobility lets you get away more easily when caught. Not only is this great for the safety that is so important for competitive play, but it gives you the option to take risks that lower mobility champions would get punished for. Typically champions pay for the mobility somewhere, but the difference between life and death decides games, so safety is just so important.

It's definitely a complex problem. The keyword is 'compensation'. Not being mobile is a huge disadvantage, and it has to be compensated appropriately. At this point in time, it's easier to give mobility than to withhold it since simpler compensations like more damage or CC don't cut it anymore, and Riot has to get creative.

Then how the hell do games like dota manage to ddo it? There are champs in that game that punish only mobile champs! Those abilities do next to nothing against immobile ones. Why cant riot implement abilities like that? Abilities that punish mobile assholes but leave immobile people not touched as much?

damage on move, damage scaling up to movespeed, damage if they move out of a certain range (lookin at u hard mobo), a damage proc on a slow or stun on a melee...

It's not that they can't; it's that the last few lines of champions almost exclusively possess knockup, poke and hard mobility. Their meta direction (and by their own words AFAIK) is that they're focusing on windows of power, and the counterargument appears to be 'mobility all the GD time'.

A champion who focuses on punishing speed or hard mobility would be fantastic, IMHO-- there's a spread enough of tanks with and without mobility, adc with and without mobility, etc. etc. that a champion designed around one or the other could surely find places to flourish.

The problem is that they cannot be exclusively focused on mobility. Otherwise, they're just a single counterpick away from meh. They also can't be singly oppressive to mobility, because then _everything else_ is just a counterpick away from being obsoleted.

cause that leads to hardcounters, which is somethin lol tries to avoid(not doing perfectly well so, but they try)
The design idea behind lols balance is counter**play**, which means that you can counteract you enemies simply by takeing action, not by buying a specific item or picking a specific champ.
Buying the right item certainly helps, so does haveing the right champ, but it isn't the main factor. The main factor is outplaying your enemie either on a taktical level or mechanically.

In dota, it is weighted diffrently, counter picks and items are the dominant element there, countering mostly happens on a macro level rather than indivitual mechanics and tactics.
I can totally understand why people prefer dota, but i personally like haveing more indivituall outplay and playmakeing potential.

What bullshit are you talking about? LOL tries to avoid hard counters"???

Yasuo has an ability that hard counters EVERY RANGED CHAMP! Morgana has an ability that counters any cc!

EVerything has counters! And everything should have counters. The problem is that mobile champs are countered less by everything than immobile ones.

We need to have tools for counterplay against mobility because mobile assholes have tools against everything else.

as i said, they try as they stated in their design-philosophy,

>While counterplay is a type of meaningful choice, it’s so important to League of Legends as a competitive multiplayer game that we consider it a pillar of our design values. A fight loses its excitement if the first punch wins – it's what you can do after that adds depth and complexity. **We try to prevent hard counters and abilities with no room for reaction**, as no game should be over without a real show of skill.

But they sadly don't get it done to well.
Also, you can play around Yasuos windwall with most champs...

And there is a huge difference between counter and hard-counter.

Because, while I like DotA2 more, I understand that this isn't DotA. DotA can implement those strategies and niche counters because IceFrog balances the game around all of that existing (hence why some heroes outright cannot buy Skull Basher, like Faceless Void, Slardar, Troll Warlord, because he knew it'd be too much), whereas League has a team who seems to be more reactionary than not. 

The games are balanced differently, which means that something that works in DotA can't necessarily work in League. I really, really wish it could, but they really can't. League champions aren't built like DotA heroes, unfortunately.

actually, the immobile champions tend to stay out of range
the mobile ones will jump in range for a moment and then back out. (because otherwise they ain't doin anything) when they jump in, then you get 'em with that homing CC
also mobile champs tend to rely on their mobility more than other champs do, so taking it from them hurts more

Right now, ranged champos imo dion't have a big enough tradeoff other than beeing squishy for their range, while imobile melees don't get compensated enough for their inherent weaknesses.

This ends with imobile melees usually melting befor they reach their opponents unless ahead in the midgame, while mobile melees can reach the squishy ranged champs and kill them fast.
You might say thats ok, you have a Rock–Paper–Scissors system as imobile melees out stat mobile melees and can bruis them down.
This has just two problems: 

  - mobile meeles can avoid the imobile ones and leave them for their rangeds to clean while they decimate the enemie backline, they often enough can take down the imobile melees theself with hit and run takkticks...

- in a game in which you stick with your choice for the next ~20-40min, it sucks incredible hard to play as a stone vs paper. It's prettymuch suffering for up to an hour...
If you have to live with your decision for such a long period, it shouldn't be a Rock–Paper–Scissors like decision, which is why riot stated at some point in their design-philosophie that they avoid hardcounters, just that they didn't keeo up with that idea to well (anyone who faced vayne as shyvana belives in hardcounters...)

Imo, ranged champs should deal less damage, but maybe have a bit more survivabillity, while mobile champs should be a slight bit more fragile.
Imobile melees on the other hand should have more sustain and tools to work around cc to make up for their lack of range and mobillity, as well as more tankiness based on the number of nearby enemies.
Garren is a great example for a kit that does somewhat work on a imobile melee, he not only has good damage/tankiness, but also a slow-remove, inbuilt tenacity, alot sustain and a silence to punish mobile melees that try to mock him.
Sadly, he still pops in no time endgame once carrys get 5-6 items like any champ that isn't allistar...

you can balance around the offset of beeing low range and/or imobile, but you have to assess the offset of thos particular advantages right, and i feel that riot underestimates how big of a disadvantage beeing melee and imobile is as soon as you get out of a 1v1 and into a 5v5 scenario.
Vs a single enemy, you can probably tank the long enough to finaly reach them and burn though their helath.
But vs 5 enemies, you eat far more damage while you also have a harder time reachin a target as more cc is comeing your way.
The only way to balance around that without haveing a overbearing 1v1 champ are mechanics that are stronger vs multiple enemies and ways to deal with high amounts of cc.

1) Lots of shit is instant death for a soft target. Rengar/Talon/Wukong can global you from stealth, Warwick can flash ult on you, etc etc. Most of these things have less counterplay - you can't dodge them, like you can any of these skillshots, they only require one member of the enemy team to execute, you can't cleanse or black shield them etc etc. These skillshots are no worse than a million other things in the game. 

2) If you remove anything that gibs or in and of itself dooms a character, LoL would be a completely different game.

3) People have to die sometime. If you get hooked into the enemy team as a carry, you fucked up. You made a huge mistake, and you deserve to pay. It's immediately apparent what you did wrong and how you can fix it. 

If this kind of mistake is survivable (and, to be honest, thresh hook and morg q are already reasonably survivable if your team's there to bail you out) then people just never die. It's boring and it slows down the game.

{{item:3140}} + {{item:1058}} or {{item:3028}} + {{item:3113}} or just make {{item:3222}} able to selfcast.

I understand how {{champion:412}} and {{champion:25}} can be frustrating, but I really don't think either of their Q's are overpowered and imbalanced. The duration of Morgana's root is really annoying, yes, but its only a root, not a stun. You can still use your champion's abilities to keep enemies away (depending on who you're playing) and you can easily cleanse it with something like a {{item:3140}} or {{item:3222}}. With Thresh, you have 3 opportunities to flash away from his full combo and avoid getting completely locked down. You can flash the hook, flay, or over the wall of his ult, and his hook does not pull you fully into the center of his team, it just drags you towards him. Plus, if you know you're up against a Thresh you can always take {{summoner:1}}. If you clease the hook as soon as it stuns you, he can't reactivate his q to jump to you. Its actually easier to avoid Thresh then a lot of people realize. But then again Thresh is my absolute favorite champion, so take that bit with a grain of salt. I may be a little biased when it comes to Thresh but I've played as and against him enough to where I understand his mechanics really well. 

{{champion:53}} on the other hand, **** THIS CHAMPION. I have hated Blitzcrank since the first time I encountered him in game and I still hate everything about his kit to this day. (I've been playing since the around the end of season 3. My first login screen was Spirit Guard Udyr.) Not only does his grab have a fast projectile speed that pulls you directly on top of him, he also has the means to pretty much guarantee that he can keep you locked down once you get there. He has a significant speed boost that most champions can't outrun so he can easily put himself in range to pull you, and this just gives him the most ridiculously overbearing lane presence out of any champion in the game. Seriously, unless the lane is pushed to your tower, there is nothing stopping him from just running straight past the minion wave to get a grab off.  If he pulls you if the center of your minion wave then his ult usually either kills or at least half healths the whole wave. When he finally gets a pull on you, you get knocked up immediately then silenced. Even if you manage to flash away after he grabs you, if he at least managed to start the animation for his knock up then the attack will follow you and you'll get knocked up anyway. Which is plenty of time for him to catch up and silence you as soon as you land. His ult has a ridiculously short cooldown for what it does too. Getting grabbed by Blitz is the most unforgiving thing in the entire game because you take a ridiculous amount of punishment for just failing to dodge a single skillshot which his kit gives him the movement speed to ensure he can hit. Still though, his current W is much better than his old one because he can't just keep his movement speed boosted almost constantly anymore and now there's a penalty for failing. 

But even after all of that, I don't think Riot should change his grab. That would completely kill Blitzcrank's kit and we'd never see him in play again. Instead, they should change his E to something other than a knockup, just some other form of CC that you can actually reduce the duration of with tenacity. If they gave him a root instead, he might think twice about trying to pull your carry without having the rest of his team be able to back him up because then your carry would still be able to attack back in that time.

Anybody else think that'd be a good idea? Maybe I'm just being biased against Blitz, but I still fail to see how his kit has any counterplay to it whatsoever.
